Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Understanding and Control of Strong-Field Molecular Ionization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ever since the development of the laser in the 1960's, scientists have sought to use lasers to directly influence chemical reactions. In this context, a pulse of laser light can be thought of as a new type of reagent that drives a chemical reaction. This project will advance the study of laser-assisted chemical reactions by making three-dimensional images of the products of such reactions. This science can contribute to the economy and to public well-being because development of these laser-based reagents could one day allow chemical synthesis of novel materials and medicines. Progress toward this goal is challenging, however, because molecules are so complicated and dynamic that it is difficult to determine the correct laser characteristics to drive a particular process. This project will use experimental feedback to guide an adaptive search of the possible laser pulses. This type of method is proven to work, but it is only as good as the feedback that drives it. The goal of these studies is to develop and exploit enhanced image-based feedback techniques that refine this approach to controlling chemical dynamics. Doing this work with undergraduate students also provides students with motivation for further scientific education and therefore helps develop a highly skilled workforce.

Interactions between strong laser fields and polyatomic molecules are at the forefront of many aspects of ultrafast science. Shaped ultrafast laser pulses can powerfully influence molecular dynamics, thus allowing access to outcomes not typically available by other means. The area of emphasis of this research program is adaptive femtosecond control, in which a learning algorithm is used to guide the construction of shaped ultrafast laser pulses that produce a desired result. In order for the adaptive search to succeed, robust, well-defined feedback is required. To this end, this team developed the capacity to use three-dimensional momentum imaging of the laser-molecule reaction products. By applying rapid three-dimensional image-based feedback to the control of photoisomerization in small hydrocarbon molecules, this team is able to examine how manipulating the electronic excitation of the molecule influences the nuclear motion, and thus affects ultrafast chemical processes. Understanding basic strong-field processes helps to guide these coherent control protocols by allowing this team to link image-based feedback to specific target states. This team will pursue several experiments that can advance the understanding of how strong-field ionization occurs in polyatomic systems, including the role that field-dressed orbitals with strong Rydberg character have on tunneling ionization in polyatomic molecules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ever since the invention of the laser people have been interested in using lasers to manipulate atoms and molecules. Many impressive results have ensued, directly or indirectly influencing many aspects of everyday life through examples such as high-speed telecommunications, atomic clocks, and laser surgery.

One tantalizing application that has not advanced as quickly as was once hoped for is the use of lasers for chemical synthesis. Using a laser to break or enhance the creation of a specific molecular bond at just the right time could introduce a fundamentally new method of creating novel materials. While a laser seems an ideal tool for such a purpose because it can provide light with specific energy and duration, and the timing between pulses can be precisely controlled, laser-based chemistry remains a challenging problem.

It turns out that energy put into one part of a molecule will often quickly dissipate into other locations. Imagine starting a pendulum swing on a grandfather clock, an easy enough task. But now imagine that pendulum being connected by springs to the pendula of a series of neighboring clocks. How do you selectively start only the original pendulum moving without disturbing the neighboring clocks too much? That illustration captures the essence of some of the challenges for laser-based manipulation of chemical bonds.

In our studies of bond rearrangement, we study the molecular analog of this problem. Laser pulses generally interact easily with the electrons in a molecule. We are interested in how the changes in the electronic states of the molecule are coupled to changes in the movement of the much more massive atomic nuclei within the molecule. Bond rearrangement, which involves breaking and reforming one or more molecular bonds, is an excellent platform for testing this behavior.

The work funded by this award has looked at bond rearrangement induced by laser pulses in a series of small gas-phase molecules, such as acetylene, ethane, methanol, ethanol, and formic acid. In some cases, we were able to show that there are multiple routes the molecules can take to accomplish a particular bond rearrangement. In other cases, we were able to tailor the laser pulses to enhance the bond rearrangement, or select between multiple routes of a specific process.  In the process of these experimental efforts, we occasionally develop technical advances that are interesting to others working on similar problems. Our basic research, along with similar efforts by others, provides a framework for more sophisticated approaches and eventually to the possibility of applications of laser-assisted chemical synthesis.   

The most important broader impact of our work is the development of highly trained undergraduate students that often continue in science, technology, engineering, or mathematical (STEM) fields. This award supported five undergraduate students. The three graduated students from this group have all gone on to graduate school in science (applied physics, physics, and aerospace engineering). The other two students are still at Augustana University and currently plan to continue their STEM education after graduation. These instructional efforts are consistent with NSF's workforce development goals. 

Our experimental work is conducted at Kansas State University?s J.R. Macdonald Laboratory in collaboration with researchers there.
